awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Combining Career Preparation with Environmental Research in Chemistry, Physics and Materials Science at the University of Oregon
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates Sites program in the NSF Division of Chemistry supports Professor Geraldine Richmond and colleagues at the University of Oregon to host REU Site: Combining Career Preparation with Environmental Research in Chemistry, Physics, and Materials Science. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program. Twelve students are recruited for 10 weeks of interdisciplinary research each summer. Students choose from 18 interdisciplinary projects that focus on environmental issues. Research activities are augmented by career building workshops that include topics such as scientific and workplace communication, entrepreneurship, ethics, negotiation, and leadership. The site provides students with cutting edge research experiences, equips them with essential career skills, and develops long term mentoring relationships. 

The faculty involved with this interdisciplinary REU program come from chemistry, physics and materials science fields, allowing students to cross the traditional academic boundaries. Examples of the projects include the development of new solar materials, syntheses and characterization of environmentally relevant catalysts, creation of greener nanoparticle systems, and increasing the fundamental understanding of oil dispersants. The broader impact of this project is that it increases the number of science undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and increases the students' success in their careers.

por.por_cntn:
For the 34th year of continuous success, the University of Oregon REU Site "Combining Career Preparation with Environmental Research in Chemistry, Physics and Materials Science" is designed for science students from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUI), providing students a research experience that allows them to explore the unknown and engage in discoveries that could make a difference in our world. It affords them a unique opportunity to increase their problem-solving capabilities beyond the textbook and teaches them how to develop a project plan, analyze the data, and draw conclusions based on the findings.

This REU program is designed to provide participants with the opportunity to use their knowledge and expertise in chemistry, physics and materials science to conduct research mainly in areas related to environmental sustainability. This focus reflects the historical commitment of the University of Oregon and the state of Oregon to environmental and sustainability issues. Our REU students can choose from projects in the laboratories of 16 faculty in chemistry and physics. All faculty mentors selected for this REU program have active research programs and have experience in mentoring undergraduate students in their laboratories. At the end of the summer, students gave presentations on their work and provided a written summary. The presentations were video recorded so that students could get a sense of their ability to communicate their science. Each year several students are selected to present their work at national meetings such as American Chemical Society and the American Physical Society.

Over the past 34 years there have been close to 360 student participants, 48 within the past 5-year funding period. Career building workshops and mentoring activities provide training and practice in transferable skills essential for success in the next stage of education and employment opportunities. 100% of the students agreed the program had an impact on the way they perceived their future in the sciences, and over 90% said it solidified their decision to attend graduate school. 4 former REU participants are currently enrolled as graduate students at UO, and several of the 2022 REU cohort have applied for admission in the current recruiting season.
